Using enzyme that has had its iron-sulfur center rendered redox-inert by prior reaction with ferricenium hexafluorophosphate, we determined the spectral change associated with formation of both the anionic and neutral forms that were generated at high and low pH, respectively, of the unique 6-cysteinyl-FMN of the enzyme. With native enzyme, electron transfer was observed within the radiolytically generated one-electron reduced enzyme but only at low pH (6.0). The kinetics and thermodynamics of this electron transfer in one-electron reduced enzyme may be compared with that studied previously in the two-electron reduced enzyme. In contrast to previous studies with two-electron reduced enzyme in which a pK a of ∼8 was determined for the flavin semiquinone, in the one-electron reduced enzyme the semiquinone was not substantially protonated even at pH 6.0. These results indicate that reduction of the iron-sulfur center of the enzyme significantly decreases the pK a of the flavin semiquinone of the active site. This provides further evidence, in conjunction with the strong magnetic interaction known to exist between the centers in the two-electron reduced enzyme, that the two redox-active centers in trimethylamine dehydrogenase are in intimate contact with one another in the active site of the enzyme. trimethylamine dehydrogenase oxdized 5-deazalumiflavinv 5-deazalumiflavin radical electron-transferring flavoprotein N-methylnicotinamide N-methylnicotinamide radical tetramethylammonium chloride gray Trimethylamine dehydrogenase (TMADH)1 from the soil pseudomonad Methylophilus methylotrophus (formerly known by the isolate designation W3A1) is a flavin- and iron-sulfur-containing enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative demethylation of trimethylamine to dimethylamine and formaldehyde (1Scrutton N.S. BioEssays. 1994; 16: 115-122Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The physiological oxidant for TMADH is the electron-transferring flavoprotein (ETF) of the organism, which becomes reduced only to the level of the semiquinone under physiological conditions (2Steenkamp D.J. Mallinson J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1976; 429: 705-719Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), giving the following overall reaction stoichiometry:N(CH3) 3+H2O+2ETFox→NH(CH3) 2+H2C=O+2ETFsqEquation 1 The reaction is thought to proceed via an initial imine product, which is then nonenzymatically hydrolyzed to the secondary amine and formaldehyde. TMADH is a member of a small but important group of amine-oxidizing flavoproteins that includes the monoamine oxidases A and B, sarcosine oxidase, and methyltryptophan oxidase. In each of these enzymes the flavin cofactor is covalently linked to the polypeptide in the active sites. In the case of TMADH this covalent linkage is to Cys-30 of the polypeptide at position 6 of the isoalloxazine ring of the FMN cofactor (4Steenkamp D.J. McIntire W.S. Kenney W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1978; 253: 2818-2824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Steenkamp D.J. Kenney W.C. Singer T.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1978; 253: 2812-2817Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Loss of this linkage by mutation of Cys-30 to alanine results in a 6-fold decrease in the initial reduction of the enzyme-bound flavin, although this step remains at least an order of magnitude faster than catalysis, which is principally rate limited by product dissociation. More significantly, loss of the covalent linkage predisposes the flavin to nucleophilic attack by hydroxide to yield 6-hydroxyl-FMN, which is catalytically inert. It is thus evident that at least in the case of TMADH the covalent linkage to cysteine prevents inactivation of the active site flavin. The covalent linkage also perturbs the spectral characteristics of the flavin, the major effect being a significant decrease in the extinction coefficient associated with the near-UV absorbance band of the native cofactor; this is essentially absent in 6-cysteinyl-FMN (5Steenkamp D.J. Kenney W.C. Singer T.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1978; 253: 2812-2817Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition to the 6-cysteinyl-FMN, which constitutes the site of amine oxidation in the enzyme, TMADH possesses a 4Fe/4S center of the bacterial ferredoxin variety (6Hill C.L. Steenkamp D.J. Holm R.H. Singer T.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 547-551Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). This second redox-active center is located in relatively close proximity (within 4.5 Å edge-to-edge) of the C-8 methyl of the covalently linked flavin (7Lim L.W. Shamala N. Mathews F.S. Steenkamp D.J. Hamlin R. Xuong N. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 15140-151461Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Lim L.W. Mathews F.S. Steenkamp D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 3075-3078Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Under certain conditions, e.g. upon reduction with high concentrations of substrate or upon reduction with dithionite in the presence of the inhibitor tetramethylammonium chloride, the enzyme can be obtained in a two-electron reduced form in which one electron is on the flavin (as the anionic semiquinone) and the other on the iron-sulfur center with the two S = 1/2 spin systems interacting strongly to give what is effectively a triplet state (9Steenkamp D.J. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1982; 207: 233-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 10Steenkamp D.J. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1982; 207: 241-252Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 11Steenkamp D.J. Singer T.P. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1978; 169: 361-369Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). This spin-interacting state exhibits an unusually strong half-field EPR signal, and its magnetic properties have been the object of considerable interest over the years (11Steenkamp D.J. Singer T.P. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1978; 169: 361-369Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 12Bellamy H.D. Lim L.W. Mathews F.S. Dunham W.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 11887-11892Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Fournel A. Gambarelli S. Guigliarelli B. More C. Asso M. Chouteau G. Hille R. Bertrand P. J. Chem. Phys. 1998; 109: 10905-10913Crossref Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The spectral contributions of the 6-cysteinyl-FMN and iron-sulfur center to the UV-visible spectral change observed upon full reduction of TMADH by reagents such as sodium dithionite have been successfully deconvoluted (21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). The two centers have very closely overlapping absorbance changes, with broad maxima in the oxidized-minus-reduced difference spectra centered at approximately 450 nm. The extinction change attributable to the two-electron reduction of 6-cysteinyl-FMN is 14.0 mm−1 cm−1, however, and that for the one-electron reduction of the iron-sulfur center 5.5 mm−1 cm−1. The spectral changes associated with formation of the neutral and anionic forms of the 6-cysteinyl-FMN have not been characterized previously. It has been demonstrated that in the course of turnover, reducing equivalents obtained by the flavin upon oxidation of substrate are passed first to the iron-sulfur center and then onto ETF (9Steenkamp D.J. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1982; 207: 233-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 10Steenkamp D.J. Beinert H. Biochem. J. 1982; 207: 241-252Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 14Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 15244-15252Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,15Jang M.-H. Basran J. Scrutton N.S. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13147-13154Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Kinetic studies of wild type and various site-directed mutants of TMADH identified a region on the surface of the enzyme nearest the buried iron-sulfur center in the vicinity of Tyr-442 as being important in this interprotein electron transfer process. Mutation of this tyrosine to a glycine, for example, reduces the limiting rate of ETF reduction (i.e. reduction within the pre-formed TMADH·ETF complex) from 186 s−1 to 6.1 s−1, while increasing the K d for the reduced enzyme-ETF complex from 16 μm to 180 μm (16Huang L. Scrutton N.S. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 13401-13406Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). Electron transfer between the 6-cysteinyl-FMN and iron-sulfur center in two-electron reduced TMADH has been examined using a pH-jump technique to perturb the distribution of reducing equivalents between the flavin and iron-sulfur center (14Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 15244-15252Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Rohlfs R.J. Huang L. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 22196-22207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The investigators find that electron transfer between the two centers is intrinsically fast, with a lower limit of approximately 1000 s−1. Significantly, coupling of prototropic equilibria to the electron transfer process, because of ionization of the flavin semiquinone and hydroquinone oxidation states, is thermodynamically linked to electron transfer to the extent that rates of electron equilibration between the two exhibit a significant pH-dependence, with apparent rate constants varying from 300 s−1 to 1000 s−1 or more over the pH range of 6–10 (18Rohlfs R.J. Huang L. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 22196-22207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). In contrast to the two-electron reduced enzyme, electron transfer within one-electron reduced TMADH has been examined previously in only one case using flash photolysis (19Hazzard J.T. McIntire W.S. Tollin G. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 4559-4564Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar). Complications arising from the disproportionation of the photolytically generated 5-deazariboflavin radical used in the study to give the hydroquinone (followed by the slow reduction of the enzyme by the hydroquinone thus generated) have seriously complicated the interpretation of the results, however (14Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 15244-15252Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Pulse radiolysis is an alternate method by which reducing equivalents can be rapidly (μs time scale) introduced into redox-active proteins and subsequent intramolecular electron transfer can be followed. This method involves the generation of quantified concentrations of strongly reducing or oxidizing species by a rapid pulse of high-energy electrons applied to an aqueous sample (20Land E.J. Swallow A.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1968; 162: 327-337Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Under appropriate conditions, the primary radiolytic radicals ( eaq−, H⋅, HO⋅) can be rapidly scavenged by added reagents to form strongly reducing species having desirable chemical properties for reaction with biological molecules. In the present work, pulse radiolytic methods (22Hille R. Anderson R.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 5608-5615Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Anderson R.F. Hille R. Stevenson K.J. Massey V. Williams Jr., C.H. Flavins and Flavoproteins. University of Calgary Press, Calgary1997: 865-868Google Scholar) were used to rapidly generate and characterize the one-electron reduced flavin semiquinone of TMADH at low and high pH, thereby establishing the UV-visible spectral changes associated with formation of these two mechanistically important species and completing the spectral characterization of the enzyme. In addition, electron transfer within the one-electron reduced enzyme was examined subsequent to the rapid initial reduction of the enzyme by radiolytically generated radicals. A comparison of the present results with those obtained previously for electron transfer within two-electron reduced enzyme indicates significant differences in behavior that relate directly to the catalytic behavior of the enzyme. Specifically, the neutral flavin semiquinone was stabilized to a greater extent in the two-electron reduced as compared with the one-electron reduced enzyme. Whereas the range of rate constants for electron transfer was comparable in the two partially reduced enzyme forms, the pH dependence of the observed rate constants was different in the one- as opposed to two-electron reduced enzyme. Trimethylamine dehydrogenase was purified from M. methylotrophus W3A1 as described initially by Steenkamp and Mallinson (2Steenkamp D.J. Mallinson J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1976; 429: 705-719Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), except that gel filtration was performed using Sephacryl S-200 rather than Sephadex G-200. An extinction coefficient of 27.3 mm−1cm−1 at 442 nm was used to determine the enzyme concentration. Phenylhydrazine-modified enzyme was prepared by incubating the enzyme with reagent (Sigma) for 4 h at room temperature in 0.1 m phosphate buffer, pH 8.0, as described by Kasprzak et al. (25Kasprzak A.A. Papas E.J. Steenkamp D.J. Biochem. J. 1983; 211: 535-541Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Ferricenium hexafluorophosphate was prepared according to the method of Thorpe and co-workers (26Lehman T.C. Hale D.E. Bhala A. Thorpe C. Anal. Biochem. 1990; 186: 280-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (219) Google Scholar, 27Lehman T.C. Thorpe C. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 10594-10602Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar); the iron-sulfur center of the enzyme was rendered redox-inert by reaction with this reagent for 4 h at room temperature in 0.1 mborate buffer, pH 10, as described previously by Huang et al. (21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) was purchased from Sigma, and 5-deazalumiflavin (dFl) was the generous gift of Dr. Vincent Massey (Dept. of Biological Chemistry, University of Michigan). All other reagents were of the highest purity commercially available and were used without further purification. Pulse radiolysis was performed using the University of Auckland computer-controlled 4 MeV Dynaray linear accelerator facility using a custom-built detection system fitted with Supracil optics. Pulses of electrons to give doses on the order of 4–6 Gy (J/kg) in 200 ns were used to initiate radical reactions under controlled conditions, with dosimetry carried out before each experimental run to quantify the yield of radicals generated with each pulse. A potassium thiocyanate dosimeter was used for this calibration using a radiation chemical yield for SCN⨪2 of 0.29 μmol/J and an extinction coefficient of 7.58 mm−1 cm−1 for the radical intermediate (28Schuler R.H. Patterson L.K. Janata E. J. Phys. Chem. 1980; 84: 2088-2089Crossref Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Under the present experimental conditions, the primary radiolytically generated radicals are the aquated electron, eaq−, HO⋅, and H⋅. By saturating the solutions with N2O, the aquated electron was rapidly converted to HO⋅ and with formate present at a concentration of 0.1 m, both H⋅ and HO⋅were converted to CO⨪2 within the electron pulse (typically 200 ns). In the presence of (0.1–2.5 mm)N-methylnicotinamide or 5-deazalumiflavin, CO⨪2 was quantitatively converted to NMN⋅ or dFl⋅ radicals within a few microseconds of the electron pulse. It is these strongly reducing radical species generated under the present experimental conditions within the first 5 μs after the pulse that represent the proximal reductants of TMADH. In separate control experiments, reduction of enzyme by NMN⋅ or dFl⋅ radicals were found to take place with second-order rate constants of 2.0 ± 0.2 × 108m−1 s−1 and 4.6 ± 0.2 × 107m−1s−1, respectively. That is, under the typical experimental conditions of ∼80 μm TMADH, enzyme was reduced with pseudo first-order rate constants of 1.6 × 104 and 3.7 × 103 s−1, respectively. Difference spectra of one-electron reduced enzyme thus generated were determined relative to pre-pulsed oxidized enzyme and are presented here as extinction change, Δε (mm−1 cm−1) taking into account the observed change in absorbance and the experimental radiolytic dose and using a value of 0.6 μm reductants produced per Gy of pulse dose. Only a limited range of wavelengths (>420 nm) could be investigated using dFl⋅ radicals as reductant because a 400-nm optical filter had to be employed so as to avoid rapid deazaflavin-sensitized photoreduction of the enzyme by the analyzing beam subsequent to the radiolytic pulse. The temperature of the pulse experiments reported here was 21 ± 1 °C. Under the conditions of the present pulse experiments, involving the generation of strongly reducing (rather than oxidizing) species, the enzyme was found to be minimally damaged during the course of the radiolytic experiment. The absorption spectrum of enzyme reoxidized after radiolysis was indistinguishable from that of the starting material and losses in activity were negligible (less than 5%). The contributions of the flavin and iron-sulfur centers of TMADH to the spectral change observed upon reduction of the enzyme with reagents such as sodium dithionite have previously been deconvoluted (13Fournel A. Gambarelli S. Guigliarelli B. More C. Asso M. Chouteau G. Hille R. Bertrand P. J. Chem. Phys. 1998; 109: 10905-10913Crossref Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The 6-thioether linkage of the FMN of TMADH significantly perturbs the absorption spectrum of the flavin chromophore. The absorption band of the oxidized cofactor centered at 440 nm is somewhat enhanced in extinction coefficient (∼16 mm−1cm−1 as opposed to ∼12 mm−1cm−1 for normal flavins), whereas the near-UV absorption band of the native cofactor at 365 nm is essentially lost. As a result, the well characterized absorption spectra for the neutral and anionic semiquinone forms of natural flavins cannot be used with TMADH. Given the fact that reduction of enzyme by substrate yields a two-electron reduced form of the enzyme in which the iron-sulfur center is reduced and the flavin is present as the anionic semiquinone, it was of interest to establish the UV-visible spectral properties of the semiquinone oxidation state of the 6-cysteinyl-FMN of TMADH. Previously, Pace and Stankovich (29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) reported the spectral change associated with the one-electron reduction of the 6-cysteinyl-FMN of TMADH to the anionic semiquinone, as observed in the course of spectroelectrochemical titrations. These experiments were carried out in the presence of the inhibitor tetramethylammonium chloride (TMAC), which proved necessary to sufficiently resolve the several electrochemical processes taking place. Just as TMAC perturbs the reduction potentials of the flavin, it likely perturbs the absorption spectrum of the anionic semiquinone, and in any case no extinction changes were reported in this earlier work. To determine the spectral change associated with formation of both the neutral and anionic forms of the flavin center of TMADH, enzyme in which the iron-sulfur center had been rendered redox-inert by prior reaction with the reagent ferricenium hexafluorophosphate at high pH (21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar) was reduced with radiolytically generated NMN⋅ radical by one equivalent, generating spectral changes of the type shown in Fig.1. The spectral changes shown are relative to the spectrum of oxidized enzyme prior to the pulse. In these experiments, it was possible to quantitate the radiolytic yield of NMN⋅ from its absorbance at 410 nm (ε = 3200m−1 cm−1, Ref. 20Land E.J. Swallow A.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1968; 162: 327-337Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar), and under our experimental conditions of high protein concentration (typically 80 μm or more) and low radiolytic dose (generating no more than 5 μm NMN⋅ immediately after pulse), the NMN⋅ was found to react essentially quantitatively with the protein with no significant formation of the (NMN)2 dimer (k dimerization = 2.0 × 109m−1 s−1, Ref. 22Hille R. Anderson R.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 5608-5615Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 1, the spectral changes observed when the experiment was performed at pH 10, generating the anionic flavin semiquinone (triangles), and at pH 7.0, generating the neutral semiquinone (squares), yield distinct difference spectra. In the case of the high pH experiment, a pronounced absorption increase at 365 nm (Δε = 3,700 m−1cm−1) was observed that has been previously ascribed to the anionic flavin semiquinone, although the spectral change associated with formation of this form of the cofactor had not otherwise been described. As seen in Fig. 1 (triangles), formation of the anionic 6-cysteinyl-FMN⨪ from the oxidized cofactor has an associated extinction change that consists of an absorbance decrease at ∼440 nm (Δε = 1, 400m−1 cm−1) and a small absorbance increase above 500 nm (Δε = 900m−1 cm−1). The changes seen at 365 and 520 nm were roughly comparable with those reported for the anionic semiquinone of normal flavins (30Massey V. Hemmerich P Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1980; 8: 246-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar) although the extinction decrease was significantly reduced. The implication is that the anionic semiquinone of 6-cysteinyl-FMN retains a considerably greater portion of the absorbance of the oxidized cofactor in this region of the absorption spectrum than is the case with normal flavins. As with the anionic semiquinone, the spectral change observed on formation of the neutral semiquinone of 6-cysteinyl-FMN at pH 7 was qualitatively similar to that seen with normal flavins (Fig. 1,squares). The 6-cysteinyl-FMNH⋅ was characterized by a long-wavelength absorbance (although the extinction change associated with formation of this species is 2200m−1 cm−1, somewhat lower than was seen with normal flavins) and a significant decrease in the 440-nm absorbance of the oxidized cofactor (Δε = −2000 m−1 cm−1, again somewhat less than the comparable spectral change seen on formation of the neutral semiquinone of normal flavins). As expected, the extinction change at 365 nm was greatly reduced for the neutral 6-cysteinyl semiquinone compared with the anionic form. Comparable spectral changes were observed for both the anionic and neutral 6-cysteinyl flavin semiquinones using dFl⋅ rather than NMN⋅ as the proximal reductant of enzyme. However, in this case it was not possible to determine spectral changes below 400 nm because of the intrinsic absorbance of the deazaflavin itself and the need to use optical filters to avoid dFl-sensitized photoreduction of the enzyme in the analyzing beam of the pulse radiolysis apparatus. In addition to the above protocol using ferricenium hexafluorophosphate to render the iron-sulfur center of TMADH redox-inert, it was also possible to react the flavin of the enzyme with phenylhydrazine to render this center redox-inert (25Kasprzak A.A. Papas E.J. Steenkamp D.J. Biochem. J. 1983; 211: 535-541Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). In this case, one-electron reduction of the enzyme by radiolytically generated NMN⋅ yielded the pH-independent spectral change associated with reduction of the iron-sulfur center. This spectral change, as shown in Fig. 2, was characterized by a broad rather featureless absorption decrease centered at ∼430 nm with an associated extinction change of −5.8 mm−1 cm−1. This extinction change is in very good agreement with that previously determined from electrochemical reduction (29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) and reductive titration (19Hazzard J.T. McIntire W.S. Tollin G. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 4559-4564Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar) of phenylhydrazine-inactivated enzyme and also in line with extinction changes for 4Fe/4S centers in other proteins (typically ∼6 mm−1cm−1, Ref. 31Stephens P.J. Thomson A.J. Dunn J.B.R. Keiderling T.A. Rawlings J. Rao K.K. Hall D.O. Biochemistry. 1978; 17: 4770-4778Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar and citations therein). With the spectral changes associated with reduction of the iron-sulfur center and formation of both the anionic and neutral forms of the flavin semiquinone established, it was now possible to interpret the spectral changes associated with the reaction of native trimethylamine dehydrogenase with radiolytically generated NMN⋅ in which electron transfer from one site to another can occur subsequent to the initial one-electron reduction of the enzyme. Electron transfer in two-electron reduced TMADH has been examined previously using a pH-jump protocol in which rate constants associated with the oxidation-reduction equilibrium FMNH2:Fe/Sox ⇆ FMN⨪:Fe/Sred have been determined. The observed rate constants for approach to the new equilibrium position subsequent to a rapid change in the solution pH are in the range 300–1000 s−1 at 25 °C with a pronounced U-shaped pH dependence (15Jang M.-H. Basran J. Scrutton N.S. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13147-13154Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Although the thermodynamics of the FMN⨪:Fe/Sox⇆ FMN:Fe/Sred equilibration in one-electron reduced enzyme was expected to be comparable with that for the above equilibration in two-electron reduced enzyme (because the reduction potentials for the quinone/semiquinone and semiquinone/hydroquinone redox couples are comparable, +44 and +36 mV, respectively, at pH 7.0, Ref. 29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar), the two processes need not exhibit the same kinetics because there is no reason to expect that the reorganization energies for formation of the flavin semiquinone and hydroquinone are the same. Furthermore, the second half-potential involves reduction to the level of the (anionic) flavin hydroquinone and thus necessarily involves the uptake of a proton; it may thus exhibit a different pH dependence than does the first half-potential. For these reasons, we investigated electron transfer within the one-electron reduced enzyme so that a comparison with the values obtained with the two-electron reduced enzyme could be made explicitly. The spectral change associated with the initial reduction of native oxidized TMADH by NMN⋅ radicals over the pH range 6–10 shows only a very small absorbance increase at 365 nm (Δε ∼500m−1 cm−1) and a decrease in absorbance in the region 380–500 nm with the maximum change in the 420 nm region (Δε ∼5,800 m−1cm−1), as shown in Fig. 4and in Fig. 5. These spectral features are consistent with the spectral change known to be associated with reduction of the 4Fe/4S center in TMADH (see Fig. 2 and Ref. 21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar), indicating that the initial rapid reduction takes place principally at the Fe/S center rather than the flavin (compare with Fig. 2). Subsequent to this initial kinetic phase, a subsequent kinetic process was observed whose rate constant was independent of enzyme concentration and had an associated spectral change reflecting formation of the red anionic flavin semiquinone with a characteristic increase in absorbance at 365 nm (see Figs. 1 and4). 2In the experiments shown in Figs. 4 and 5, reoxidation of the iron-sulfur center of TMADH is necessarily concomitant with reduction of the flavin to give the semiquinone in the course of intramolecular electron transfer. The spectral change associated with iron-sulfur reoxidation is known to be centered on the absorption maximum of the 6-cysteinyl-FMN of the enzyme although with only about one-third the extinction of that attributed to the flavin (13Fournel A. Gambarelli S. Guigliarelli B. More C. Asso M. Chouteau G. Hille R. Bertrand P. J. Chem. Phys. 1998; 109: 10905-10913Crossref Scopus (32) Google Scholar). It is thus very difficult to deconvolute the specific spectral change associated with reoxidation of the iron-sulfur center in the present experiments. Both these observations were consistent with the observed process involving intramolecular electron transfer from the Fe/S center to the flavin within the one-electron reduced enzyme. We note that the apparent differences in the 400–550 nm region between the spectra for the red anionic flavin semiquinone shown in Figs. 1 and 3 are because of differences in absorption spectra for the ferricenium hexafluorophosphate-treated and native enzyme, respectively, and not because of changes in the absorbance of the semiquinone. The magnitude of the spectral change associated with intramolecular electron transfer within native one-electron reduced enzyme was small, indicating that electron transfer from the iron-sulfur center to the 6-cysteinyl-FMN occurred to only a relatively small extent. This is consistent with electron transfer from the Fe/S center to the flavin being thermodynamically uphill (see below). Similar results were obtained when dFl⋅ was used as the proximal reductant of the enzyme,i.e. initial reduction occurred at the Fe/S center followed by intramolecular electron transfer; a similar spectrum to that seen upon reduction of the enzyme by NMN⋅ was observed (Fig. 3).Figure 5Overall spectral change following the one-electron reduction of native TMADH by NMN⋅ and dFl ⋅ radicals. Comparison of the absorption spectrum of native TMADH at pH 6–7 (circles) with one-electron reduced enzyme produced on reaction with (i) NMN⋅ radicals measured after 2 ms (squares), and (ii) dFl⋅ radicals measured after 1 ms (triangles). The spectrum representing the one-electron reduced enzyme is constructed from the spectral data presented in Fig.3 corrected for the radiolytic loss in the absorption of the native enzyme because the electron pulse assumes a reducing radical yield of 0.6 μm Gy−1).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Figure 3The reaction of radiolytically generated NMN⋅ and dFl ⋅ radicals with native TMADH. Spectral changes observed following pulse radiolysis of a N2O-saturated solution containing sodium formate (0.1m) and TMADH (126 μm), NMN+ (2.5 mm), and phosphate (10 mm, pH 6), where (i) the initially formed NMN⋅ radical (circles, measured immediately after the pulse of 10 Gy in 0.2 μs producing a radical yield of 6.8 μm) decays rapidly within 50 μs to the second spectrum (inverted triangles, ▿), which in turn decays within 2 ms to a third spectrum (squares); and (ii) TMADH (83 μm), deazaflavin (0.1 mm) and phosphate (10 mm, pH 7) where a partial spectrum (triangles, ▵) resulting from the reaction of dFl⋅radicals is measured 1 ms after the pulse (4 Gy in 0.2 μs producing a radical yield of 2.7 μm). Reduction of enzyme by NMN⋅ or dFl⋅ radicals was found to take place with second-order rate constants of 2.0 ± 0.2 × 108m−1 s−1 and 4.6 ± 0.2 × 107m−1 s−1, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The rate constant for intramolecular electron equilibration from the reduced Fe/S center to 6-cysteinyl-FMN was found to be pH-dependent, increasing by a factor of almost 10 from 210 ± 22 s−1 at pH 10.0 to 1860 ± 260 s−1 at pH 6.0. This result contrasts to that seen with two-electron reduced enzyme where the fastest apparent rates of electron transfer were seen at high rather than low pH. The rate of electron transfer was also studied in D2O at pD 6.0, where a considerable decrease in the rate constant for electron transfer compared with that in water was observed to a value of 139 ± 37 s−1. The effective solvent kinetic isotope effect of 13.4 ± 1.9 was surprisingly large given that the unprotonated anionic flavin semiquinone was formed in the reaction. The effect possibly arises from the sequential electron transfer from reduced Fe/S center and protonation of a small proportion of the red flavin semiquinone at pH 6. Both the kinetic and spectral data imply that for a blue flavin semiquinone to exist in one-electron reduced native protein, then its pK a would have to be lower that 5.5. Unfortunately, this could not be confirmed in the present study because the enzyme is unstable below pH 6.0. The present work has permitted the spectral characterization of the anionic and neutral semiquinone forms of the unusual 6-cysteinyl-FMN center of TMADH. In both cases the spectra were generally reminiscent of the spectra observed for the corresponding species seen with the native flavin cofactor although in each case there were important differences. The spectrum of the anionic semiquinone in particular is of particular interest as it relates to the absorption spectrum manifested by two-electron reduced enzyme upon formation of the unique spin-interacting state manifested by TMADH. Previous work demonstrated that the anionic form of the semiquinone is required for the interaction (15Jang M.-H. Basran J. Scrutton N.S. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13147-13154Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Thus, the UV-visible absorption spectrum of the enzyme in the spin-interacting state exhibited the characteristic maximum at 365 nm as well as a shoulder at 510 nm, reflecting the participation of the anionic form of the semiquinone specifically. Formation of the spin-interacting state per sedoes not give rise to a distinctive absorption spectrum but the observed spectrum of the enzyme in this state is the simple sum of the contributions of the flavin anionic semiquinone and reduced iron-sulfur center (18Rohlfs R.J. Huang L. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 22196-22207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The present work demonstrates that these spectral features are attributable to the anionic form of the semiquinone and at the same time permits a determination of the extinction coefficient for the semiquinone. The spectral change reported here for formation of the anionic semiquinone was generally similar to that described previously by Pace and Stankovich (29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) in the presence of TMAC. The ratio of the extinction changes at 365 and 440 nm was larger in the present work (it was approximately 1:1 in the work of Pace and Stankovich (29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) and more than 3:1 here, see Fig. 1), and the absorbance change above 500 nm seen here was not observed in the earlier work. These observations indicate that binding of TMAC that was used in the previous study does indeed perturb the absorption spectrum of the flavin semiquinone. Intramolecular electron transfer observed subsequent to the initial radiolytic reduction of TMADH by one equivalent is found to be quite fast, as expected given the close proximity of the two redox-active centers in the enzyme. The rate constant for electron transfer increases from 210 s−1 at pH 10 to 1860 s−1at pH 6. Although the range of values observed was comparable with that seen for electron transfer within two electron-reduced enzyme (in which the flavin semiquinone/hydroquinone rather than quinone/semiquinone couple is func- tioning), the trend is the opposite. In two-electron reduced enzyme, the observed rate constant for electron transfer triples from ∼300 s−1 at pH 7 to approximately 1000 s−1 at pH 10 (14, 18). The basis for this difference in pH dependence necessarily has to do with the involvement of the additional prototropic equilibria associated with formation of the flavin hydroquinone in the case of electron transfer in two-electron reduced enzyme (involving discrete ionizations associated with the flavin semiquinone as well as the hydroquinone, Ref. 18Rohlfs R.J. Huang L. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 22196-22207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). Electron transfer occurring from the iron-sulfur center to the 6-cysteinyl flavin is thermodynamically uphill, in that the reduction potential for the flavin quinone/semiquinone couple is some 60 mV lower than that for the iron-sulfur center (+44 mV for the quinone/semiquinone half-potential as compared with +102 mV for the Fe/S potential, Ref. 29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). Given that the initial reduction event occurred entirely (within experimental error) at the iron-sulfur center, the spectral change observed was associated with the small re-equilibration between the centers to give the 10:1 ratio of reduced iron-sulfur to flavin semiquinone expected on the basis of the difference in potentials. In light of the known pK aof ∼8.0 for the semiquinone in two-electron reduced enzyme (18Rohlfs R.J. Huang L. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 22196-22207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar), it is surprising that for the one-electron reduced enzyme the anionic form of the semiquinone was observed even at low pH. The implication is that the oxidation state of the iron-sulfur center (oxidized when the flavin semiquinone forms in one-electron reduced enzyme but reduced when the semiquinone forms in two-electron reduced enzyme) influences the pK a of the flavin semiquinone. The direction of the effect on pK a can be rationalized on electrostatic grounds: the additional negative electric charge on the reduced iron-sulfur cluster upon reduction makes it more likely for the flavin to become protonated. Nevertheless, the magnitude of the effect, amounting to a pK a shift of at least two, was surprisingly large. Even more surprising is the fact that whereas only the red anionic from of the flavin semiquinone was observed in the course of radiolytic reduction of the native enzyme, the neutral form of the semiquinone could be readily generated upon radiolytic reduction of the ferricenium-inactivated enzyme. It is possible that chemical modification in addition to oxidation of the iron-sulfur center has occurred in the course of the reaction. Ferricenium is known to be a quite powerful oxidant capable of oxidizing tyrosine residues under the present reaction conditions of high pH (32Conrads T. Hille R. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 7787-7791Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar), although we noted that no such radical species was observed in the reaction of this reagent with TMADH (21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). These points concerning the ionization of the flavin notwithstanding, the present results indicate that electron transfer within one-electron TMADH is from one to two orders of magnitude faster than turnover throughout the pH range 6–10, as is the case within two-electron reduced enzyme. This is important as the behavior of the one-electron reduced state has been implicated in accounting for the otherwise counterintuitive steady-state inhibition of TMADH by high concentrations of substrate (21Huang L. Rohlfs R.J. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 23958-23965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 33Roberts P. Basran J. Wilson E.K. Hille R. Scrutton N.S. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 14927-14940Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 17Jang M.-H. Scrutton N.S. Hille R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12546-12552Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). The one-electron reduced form of the enzyme does accumulate in the steady-state after reaction of oxidized enzyme with an equivalent of trimethylamine, followed by reaction with one equivalent of ETF, with the electron distribution between reduced iron-sulfur on the one hand and flavin semiquinone on the other being perturbed by substrate. (Substrate and substrate-analog binding is known to stabilize the semiquinone formation at the expense of iron-sulfur reduction in the one-electron reduced enzyme (29Pace N. Stankovich M. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 287: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar).) To the extent that this occurs, the enzyme will be unable to react with trimethylamine because this is an obligatory two-electron process, and inhibition is expected. The behavior of the enzyme in the steady-state is accounted for in the context of this argument, which in turn is based on the assumption that electron transfer between the two centers is intrinsically rapid compared with catalysis. The present work demonstrates that this is indeed the case.

A naturally occurring point mutant of human apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I), V156E, which is associated with extremely low plasma apoA-I and high density lipoprotein (HDL) levels, and coronary artery disease (Huang, W., Sasaki, J., Matsunaga, A., Nanimatsu, H., Moriyama, K., Han, H. Kugi, M., Koga, T., Yamaguchi, K., and Arakawa, K. (1998) Arterioscler. Throm. Vasc. Biol. 18, 389-396), was produced in an Escherichia coli expression system. The purified recombinant proapoA-I V156E mutant was examined in its structural and functional properties, both, in the lipid-free and lipid-bound states. In the lipid-free form the mutant protein exhibited small changes in conformation, but was more stable, and quite resistant to self-association, compared with control apoA-I. The V156E mutant was able to interact with phospholipid (PL) at high PL:protein ratios (95:1, mol/mol), but was inefficient in forming reconstituted HDL (rHDL) complexes at lower PL:protein ratios (40:1). In the lipid-bound, rHDL state, the mutant protein was somewhat more alpha-helical and formed a larger complex (110 A) than control apoA-I (97 A). Furthermore, the rHDL particles containing the V156E mutant did not rearrange to smaller particles in the presence of low density lipoproteins, and had minimal reactivity with lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), compared with rHDL particles made with control apoA-I. These results suggest a key role for Val-156, or the adjacent central region of apoA-I in the modulation of apoA-I conformation, stability, and self-association in solution, and in the formation of small HDL, the conformational adaptability of apoA-I leading to structural rearrangements of HDL, and the activation of LCAT.

In most animal cells, a pair of centrioles resides in the centrosome —an organelle that organizes the cell's microtubule system. It has long been thought that the two centrioles always remain at right angles to each other. It seems, however, that the 'daughter' centriole roams extensively throughout the cell.
